comments.commentBody: Eh!  8 and 8 at this rate.

Hey Lola from spain, are you a Basque separatist? Your country has been filled with a long history of human misery and colonialism. How quaint of you to forget all the human suffering the spanish empire caused. Just because your once great nation is now a mere shadow  of itself and a welfare state doesn't mean my observations of Af/Pak are incorrect. If I had to evaluate which country caused more global suffering ol Espaniol and the English empire would top the list. As far as the USA being lawless, it aint lawless if you have lots of spanish gold-- Lola!

Appears that the time to stop this is now. Cancel the program as seems the only winners are Cetusa and the companies that reap the cheap labor.

“This is a beautiful, great program,” Rick Anaya, Cetusa’s chief executive, said of the cultural exchange.

Mr. Anaya said he was aware that the work in Palmyra was strenuous. “It is hard to lift,” he said. “But they get used to it and they are fine with it after a week or so.”

Investigate weaselily Mr. Anaya. And then put him to work at the same plant he thinks isn't so hard for $8 per hour. Bet he buckles within two to three days.
Stuff like this happens in university frat houses every day. Just let them live and have their fun and games.

I don't see the need for separate sex schools, but denying that boys and girls have different attitudes towards school and may prefer different ways of learning feels more like political narrative on your part, and is not really a helpful position.

A guy from Harvard who competes against products of the football factories of LSU, Alabama, Auburn, etc, where football coaches are paid 50x as much as professors (& pressured to give passing grades to young man who don't pay attention in class if they show up at all, dedicating the bulk of their time to football, not studies) is indeed an underdog. If he were trying to be a lawyer, businessman or yes, President of the U.S., he would be a prohibitive favorite, but he is obviously an underdog in this context. Sorry Mr. Rhoden, but this is just silly.

www.newyorkgritty.net

The key is to find the right balance for each student. I can see clear benefits for both mixed and single sex schooling - as long as opportunities to socialize with members of the opposite sex exist there really isn't any harm in having a classroom with all boys, all girls, or a mix of the two.

The most important thing is making sure that everyone in your classroom irrespective of sex, race or creed gets the support and environment they need to learn.

This talk of compulsory co-ed classes is a distraction from the real issue.

Amen. I agree with everything Mr. Fabes' research has shown. Single-sex education is discriminatory and creates an environment so unlike the real world that I believe it does a great disservice to students. No taxpayer money should be spent on such ridiculous theories of education.

Just because something is legal does not make it wise. I have experienced both single-sex and coed education, and it's hard for me to believe that gender stereotypes are truly "moderated" by segregating the genders. For me, it was exactly the opposite.

I went to an all girls school. And some of us did very well indeed. However I think the good thing about asingle sex school is not the academics but that it creates a isolated place, away from all the thrill of sex, where you can not worry too much about what you wear beyond how you can distort a school uniform to look fashion.  At the time I begged my parent to take me out and put me in the local public school. But in retrospect it was a haven. I am going to dothe same for my kids when they get to high school. Costs, but I believe in it.

"Voluntary" single-sex programs is a misnomer. The programs are voluntary for parents, but rarely do students have a say in where they go to school. Students -- not parents -- are the ones harmed by single-sex education. I certainly would not have chosen it for myself, yet in the name of "school choice" parents are allowed to dictate their children's experiences. The idea of public schools in which all children receive a similarly adequate education may sound utopian, but it should not be so readily dismissed.

I agree. My son is a boysy boy and has had a time of during elementary school not being able to sit still or focus. The girls can. The boys, particularly some boys, cannot. And yes this is why the girls are beating them at everything. So I took my son to the private high school tour. I was thrilled after walking around the male teacher turned to the boys, all of whom were on their best behavior, and said "see that building over there? That is where we are going next. See who can get their first! And the boys exploded. Tearing over to the next building shouting and yelling. Once there they calmed down, chilled out and met us happily. This school had been around for over a hundred years. I think they had learned something about teaching boys.

The irony is that proponents of single-sex education claim it diminishes gender stereotypes, yet stereotype is intrinsic to gender-specific classrooms, as the example of boys with Nerf bats and girls without timed tests demonstrates.

Single-sex education at the college level, by which point students will hopefully have learned to interact with both genders, is a very different animal than single-sex education for elementary school students. An 18-year-old can make an informed decision about college, but a seven-year-old should not be subjected to segregation by gender, especially during the formative years in which children should learn to get along with everyone, male or female, not just people who look as they do.

Tragic, yet sadly hilarious. The irony of a program introducing our great nation to the youth of the world, for which one pays to travel far from their home, only to work arduous hours performing back-breaking labor and end up in debt without achieving the original goal to visit and learn about the US is priceless. I can visualize the brochure: "You will be packing chocolate gift boxes in a candy factory in rustic Pennsylvania. For this you will receive an ordinary worker's wage and experience life in our capitalist paradise." All written in English, you can be sure. So they arrive expecting to package Mother's Day and Christmas boxes of assorted chocolates, only to discover a quite different reality. This strikes me as a cautionary tale for all that could only happen in today's USA; to be taken advantage of by religious cronies of Bush's vision of America is what it means to be a worker in this economy. Poor kids. At least we have discovered another candidate for a movement: Occupy Hershey Pennsylvania and be rid of CETUSA.
How about Guy Kawasaki, the original Apple evangelist (after Mr. Jobs himself)--was he there?

psst! kofender et. al.!

Please ask Mr. Daisey if he's given up his iPhone or his MacBook just yet. You'll be surprised.

I really don't understand the narrative that the broad Tea Party has a more precise agenda while The Occupy movement does not. While the Tea Party held signs demanding "less/smaller government", they haven't proposed exactly how. To the contrary, some held signs demanding protection for their Medicare benefits. The Occupy protests against "corporate greed" are indeed vague, but the demands to tax the rich are less vague.

I suspect the media finds far it easier to be condescending and judgmental towards a movement that is young and edgy than one that is old and covered in American flag paraphernalia. We've been taught this since we were whipper-snappers! "Respect your elders" has skewed the coverage.

I think I saw a cultural turning point in the widespread(and understandable) deification of Steve Jobs in the current issue of Rolling Stone. Jobs is on the cover with the lead article title - "The Steve Jobs Nobody Knew", They made note of the huge influence Bob Dylan had on Jobs, without saying of course, their paper's very name came from Bob Dylan. More importantly, inside was a small note from the founder and publisher, Jan Wenner.

Wenner and Jobs both came of age in the sixties in San Francisco and Wenner tells us "we both took a healthy amount of LSD, which he said was one of the most important things in his life". Some people knew jobs, Wenner tripped with him! And Wenner has real bragging rights too. His long list of great writers and stories could fill a book, everyone from Hunter Thompson to currently Matt Taibbii - who was several years ahead of the pack on the Wall Street furor. So you who might have only smoked a joint with Jobs, sorry, Jan tripped with him! Who knew? Hallucinogenic drugs as a one up???

Jobs himself, an intensely private person, might have felt slightly awkward about something like this.

In any event, all such ceremonies are about the living, not the dead.

Seriously, what about Woz? Was he not there?
Last I knew he and Steve still had a decent relationship, I wonder if that's not the case?
Could be Woz has been relegated to the Apple memorial on Wednesday.

Right, a lot of people don't like software patents but very few of those people (or, for that matter, people in general) think that patents as a whole are unnecessary or bad. Dyson doesn't write software or apply for patents on software, so his views are at best tangential to the software patent debate.

Fired for warning about a "tricky" question? It's time to put the brakes on the Javerts of education. Sure you have the flagrant offenders, those who supply the answers or those who tamper with answer sheets post-test, but seriously, does warning about a question warrant such a draconian punishment? The fate of Ms. Kim is a clear example of a politically motivated stunt to deflect any whispers of tolerated cheating. Cheating at a charter school? No, that only happens at public schools. We'll just let one go to show how serious we are.

Sure, fire the flagrant offenders, and punish the other transgressors. But the punishment must be proportionate to the offense, otherwise, what are we teaching the students? We don't live in a black and white world, and our education system should reflect that. Even the multiple choice exams reflect that: "choose the BEST answer". The "best answer" is never going to be a statement along the extremes. The "best answer" usually does not feature strongly polarizing words such as "always" or "never" or be as black-and-white. But the education system has made such a choice and a bad one at that.

“Although we had no hard evidence, the soft evidence led us to make a decision to let her go"

Wow. Such boneheadedness is why I rarely respected school administrators. Firing Ms. Kim was clearly not the best answer here. At least she had the courage to take the risk to warn the students because she gave a damn about their future. The administrators cowered behind their zero tolerance rule. The Times should go back to Promise Academy and ask her former students the following question:

Under what circumstances will you warn students about a tricky question on a test?

A) Never. Giving warnings or hints on a test is cheating.
B) It is OK to do it out of care because the students need the help.
C) It is OK to do it out of care, but just don't get caught.

What do you think they will really answer when it doesn't count for a grade?
I can't decide if Thomas' subject and predicate (in his first sentence) are in agreement.  I do not think so.
